content.question: A student attempts to prepare a buffer solution with a <math alttext="p H" overflow="scroll"><mtext>pH</mtext></math> of <math alttext="10.0" overflow="scroll"><mn>10.0</mn></math> by adding <math alttext="N a H C O 3" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>NaHCO</mtext><mn>3</mn></msub></math> (<math alttext="p K sub a, equals 10.3" overflow="scroll"> <mtext>p</mtext> <msub> <mi>K</mi> <mi>a</mi> </msub> <mo>=</mo> <mn>10.3</mn> </math>) and <math alttext="N a 2 C O 3" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>Na</mtext><mn>2</mn></msub><msub><mtext>CO</mtext><mn>3</mn></msub></math> to distilled water. Instead of the desired <math alttext="p H" overflow="scroll"><mtext>pH</mtext></math>, the measured <math alttext="p H" overflow="scroll"><mtext>pH</mtext></math> of the buffer solution is <math alttext="9.5" overflow="scroll"><mn>9.5</mn></math>. Which of the following is the most likely reason that the <math alttext="p H" overflow="scroll"><mtext>pH</mtext></math> is too low?

choices.label: Too much <math alttext="N a H C O 3" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>NaHCO</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></math> was used.
Too much <math alttext="N a 2 C O 3" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>Na</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><msub><mi>CO</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></math> was used.

There was water in the flask before <math alttext="N a H C O 3" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>NaHCO</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></math> and <math alttext="N a 2 C O 3" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>Na</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><msub><mi>CO</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></math> were added.
In order to prepare the buffer, a few drops of a strong base should have been added.

content.answer: Too much <math alttext="N a H C O 3" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>NaHCO</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></math> was used.

skill.text: 6.G: Explain how potential sources of experimental error may affect the experimental results.
